conclusion: Point light source S emits two types of monochromatic light: A and B.
Monochromatic light A and B form an illuminated circular area on the water surface.
The small circular area is illuminated by polychromatic light (both A and B).
The large circular area is illuminated only by monochromatic light B.
The refractive indices of water for light A and B are given as n_1 and n_2, respectively.
When light travels from water to air, refraction occurs.
The boundary of the illuminated area corresponds to the critical angle for total internal reflection.
The critical angle for light A is determined by Snell's law: sin θ_cA = 1/n_1.
The critical angle for light B is determined by Snell's law: sin θ_cB = 1/n_2.
The small circular area is illuminated by polychromatic light (both A and B).
Monochromatic light B reaches the boundary and refracts into the air.
The sine value of the refraction angle for light B at this boundary is determined by Snell's law: n_2 sin θ_B = 1 sin θ_air.
Since the light is at the boundary of the small circular area, it corresponds to the critical angle for light B: sin θ_B = 1/n_2.
The sine value of the refraction angle of monochromatic light B at the boundary of the small circular area is: sin θ_B = 1/n_2.
